#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Ruhi Hamid

#Text=Ruhi Hamid is a British filmmaker , born in Tanzania of Asian origin , who has made award-winning documentaries for the BBC , Channel 4 , Al Jazeera International , and other UK , US and European broadcasters .

#Text=Her films have covered international stories — in Africa , Asia , Europe , South America , the USA , and the Middle East — dealing with social and political issues about women religion , poverty , health , and human rights . [ 1 ]
#Text=A graduate of London 's Royal College of Art , she is also a graphic designer . [ 2 ]
#Text=Biography
#Text=Early years
#Text=Ruhi Hamid was born in Mwanza , Tanzania , to Asian parents , [ 3 ] and moved to England at the age of 12 . [ 2 ]

#Text=After earning a BA in Information Graphics from Middlesex Polytechnic in 1980 , she attended London 's Royal College of Art , and on graduating worked as a graphic designer : in the Netherlands with the influential Studio Dumbar , [ 2 ] in Zimbabwe as part of a collective of young black designers and photographers , the Maviyane Project , and in London at the BBC for several years . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=Film career

#Text=She began her filmmaking career with the BBC 's Community Programme Unit on the BAFTA award-winning series Video Diaries and Video Nation , [ 6 ] before leaving in May 2000 to work as a freelance producer/director . [ 7 ]

#Text=For her debut as a freelance , she gained unprecedented access to the Pakistani criminal courts to make the three-part Channel 4 series Lahore Law ( 2002 ) , which was nominated for a Grierson Award . [ 7 ]
#Text=Specialising as a solo director/camerawoman , often at significant personal risk , [ 8 ]

#Text=she went on to make other well regarded films for the BBC , Channel 4 , Arte and Al Jazeera International , including Women and Islam ( 2004 ) , The Rockstar and the Mullahs ( 2003 ) , [ 4 ] and Women , Weddings , War and Me ( featuring Nelufar Hedayat , 2010 ) . [ 9 ] [ 10 ]
#Text=Hamid has also collaborated with prominent broadcasters including Jonathan Dimbleby and BBC Three 's Reggie Yates . [ 11 ]
#Text=Her films have been described as " informative journeys into the world of people and their cultures " , [ 5 ]

#Text=her projects having included documentaries about the Hmong people trapped in the jungle of Laos [ 12 ] ( she filmed the first ever footage of their plight and went on to campaign on their behalf at the United Nations , the US State Department and at the EU Commission in Brussels ) , [ 8 ] [ 13 ] farmers in China , New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina , [ 3 ]

#Text=gang crime and violence in Cape Flats , South Africa , [ 6 ] and At the Epicentre , a film on the aftermath of the Asian tsunami in Banda Aceh , Indonesia , that won the Rory Peck Award in 2005 . [ 4 ] [ 14 ]
#Text=She has also campaigned through video for greater awareness of people with HIV/AIDS in rural India . [ 3 ]
#Text=According to ESPN ,

#Text=" Hamid 's empathy and gift for understanding the ordinary person has enabled her to gain access to peoples , cultures and institutions around the world , including the Amazonian Indians , Shamans in the Siberian forests , refugees in Uganda , women in Afghanistan and the British Foreign & Commonwealth office in Pakistan .
